description: From Middle English *special, especial, especiall, from Old French especial (whence also French spécial), from Latin speciālis (from speciēs). Displaced native Old English synderlīċ.  Doublet of especial.

adjectives.description: special (comparative more special or specialer, superlative most special or specialest)

entries.meaning: Distinguished by a unique or unusual quality.
examples: a special episode of a television series

entries.meaning: Of particular personal interest or value; dear; beloved.
(euphemistic) Of or related to disabilities, especially learning or intellectual disabilities.
examples: He goes to a special school.

entries.meaning: Constituting or relating to a species.
examples: The seven dark spots is a special property unique to Coccinella septempunctata.

entries.meaning: (military) Of or related to unconventional warfare.
A reduction in consumer cost (usually for a limited time) for items or services rendered.
examples: We're running a special on turkey for Thanksgiving.

entries.meaning: One of a rotation of meals systematically offered for a lower price at a restaurant.
examples: Today's special is our tuna melt on rye.

entries.meaning: (broadcasting) Unusual or exceptional episode of a series.
examples: Did you see the Christmas special?

entries.meaning: Anything that is not according to normal practice, plan, or schedule, as an unscheduled run of transportation that is normally scheduled.
examples: Thousands came to see the special that carried the President's coffin.

entries.meaning: Any unlicensed medicine produced or obtained for a specific individual patient.
(journalism) A correspondent; a journalist sent to the scene of an event to report back.
(journalism) A dispatch sent back by a special correspondent.
(theater) A light that illuminates a specific person or thing on the stage.
examples: In addition to followspots, there will be three frontlight specials on Autoyokes hung on the truss to provide frontlight specials.

entries.meaning: (law) A person appointed specifically to examine a single event or issue.
examples: For the few times the U.S. Supreme Court has to actually try a case, they will appoint a special master to do so.
After the Watergate break in, a special prosecutor was appointed.

verbs.description: special (third-person singular simple present specials, present participle specialing or specialling, simple past and past participle specialed or specialled)
